intro: Romulea ligustica subsp. vaccarii, commonly known as the Vaccarii squill, is a member of the Iridaceae family and is native to the Mediterranean region. It is characterized by its compact, bulbous rhizomes and produces striking, bell-shaped flowers in shades of white and yellow. The plant typically blooms in spring and is often found in rocky or sandy soils. It is a perennial herb that thrives in well-drained environments. Due to its ornamental value, it is cultivated in gardens, though it requires specific conditions to flourish.
